question: Over the past six months, my menstrual cycles have stayed roughly regular, but the intensity of my cramps has increased and I’ve developed a scattering of thicker facial hairs on my upper lip. I recently switched to a high-stress remote job where I regularly sleep only 5–6 hours per night, and I’ve also noticed new cravings for high-carb foods during the second half of my cycle. Given the constellation of subtle androgenic changes, sleep disruption, and new food cravings, could this pattern still fit within a PCOS-related hormonal imbalance even though my cycles remain predictable?
correct_answer: Yes, because PCOS can present with stable cycle timing while still producing androgen-related symptoms that worsen under high stress and poor sleep.
incorrect_answers: Yes, but only if cycle irregularity is already well established prior to the onset of stress.
No, because regular cycles exclude the possibility of PCOS-related hormonal instability.
No, because facial hair changes only occur as a result of perimenopause, not PCOS.
